courses.course_description: An introductory course for students who wish to begin their study of Spanish. It teaches the four skills - listening, speaking, reading, and writing. The class meets four days a week (with the exception of the online section, which taught completely online). Class time is used to integrate new structures and vocabulary into spoken and written language.

This designated honors section of Elementary Spanish will challenge students to explore more deeply the currently existing thematic units of the SPAN 1100 curriculum.  Students will participate in group discussions, creative projects, independent study and use of authentic written and aural material from primary sources.  Honors Spanish 1100 will integrate cultural events outside the classroom such as movies, guest lectures, art exhibits, seminars or concerts as available.  Once a semester, Honors Spanish 1100 will meets with Honors SPAN 1200H and SPAN 2100H as a cohort group for further intellectual exchange and enrichment.  Graded on A-F basis only.

The second course of the beginning sequence in the continuation of SPAN 1100.  It places equal emphasis on the four skills; listening, speaking, reading, and writing.  Students who have prior knowledge of Spanish are encouraged to take this course.  NO credit for both SPAN 1200 and SPAN 1250.
courses.prerequisites: Grade of C or better in SPAN 1100 or equivalent

courses.course_description: This course, designed for students who have taken SPAN 1100 or an equivalent course and enrolled in the Honors College, offers an introduction to the Spanish language and the many cultures in encompasses.  Your course work will allow you to develop all four language skills: reading, speaking, listening and writing along with the cultural background necessary to help you to communicate effectively in Spanish.  With the honors designation section, the course will allow students to access greater challenges in the existing thematic units in the curriculum through group discussion, creative projects and authentic situations.  Graded on A-F basis only.
Organized study of selected topics. Subjects may vary from semester to semester. May be repeated with departmental consent.
courses.prerequisites: SPAN 1200 with a grade of C or better

courses.course_description: Organized study of selected topics. Subjects may vary from semester to semester. May be repeated with departmental consent.
courses.prerequisites: SPAN 1200 with a grade of C or better

courses.course_name: Undergraduate Topics in Spanish-Humanities/Fine Arts - Honors
courses.course_description: Organized study of selected topics. Subjects may vary from semester to semester. May be repeated with departmental consent.
courses.prerequisites: SPAN 1200 with a grade of C or better.  Honors eligibility required

courses.course_description: A multi-skill course following SPAN 1200, centering on cultural/ literary readings, and including a grammar review, practice in the spoken language, as well as some practice in written expression.
courses.prerequisites: grade of C or better in SPAN 1200 or SPAN 1250, or their equivalent courses

courses.course_description: A multi-skill course following SPAN 1200, centering on cultural/literary readings, and including a grammar review, practice in the spoken language, as well as some practice in written expression.  The course seeks to improve student's fluency in Spanish and to expose them to the many cultures it encompasses.  This course will integrate cultural events outside the classroom as well such as movies, guest lectures, art exhibits, seminars or concerts as available.  Graded on A-F basis only.

First course following required elementary sequence.  Designed specifically to correct any remaining weaknesses in gross writing skills and to develop further conversational ability with equal emphasis on both of these aspects.  Classwork involves written compositions and oral presentations.

courses.course_name: Intermediate Spanish Composition and Conversation - Honors
courses.course_description: First course following required elementary sequence.  Designed specifically to correct any remaining weaknesses in gross writing skills and to develop further conversational ability with equal emphasis on both of these aspects.  Classwork involves written compositions and oral presentations.
courses.prerequisites: SPAN 2100 or equivalent.  Honors eligibility required

courses.course_description: Survey of Spanish history, arts and culture. Open to any student interested. No knowledge of Spanish required. May not be included in area of concentration in Spanish.
(same as PEA_ST 2320). Study of the Spanish Civil War: History, Politics, Literature.  May not be included in the area of concentration in Spanish.
Survey of Latin American history, arts and culture. Open to any student interested. No knowledge of Spanish required. May not be included in area of concentration in Spanish.

This course studies the literature of Hispanic minorities in the United States: Chicanos (Mexican American), Mainland Puerto Ricans, and Cuban exile writers. It explores the question of minority versus majority literatures and the creation of a Hispanic minority discourse. No knowledge of Spanish required.
Organized study of selected topics. Subjects and earnable credit may vary from semester to semester. May be repeated for credit with departmental consent.
Organized study of selected topics. Subjects and earnable credit may vary from semester to semester. May be repeated for credit with departmental consent.
Organized study of selected topics. Subjects and earnable credit may vary from semester to semester. May be repeated for credit with departmental consent.

Course puts into practice the linguistic skills learned at intermediate levels.  It develops and increases the capacity for comprehension and oral expression in the language.  Focus is on practice of certain syntactic structures and idiomatic expressions, and on acquisition of new vocabulary.

Course puts into practice the linguistic skills learned at intermediate levels.  It develops and increases the capacity for comprehension and oral expression in the language.  Focus is on practice of certain syntactic structures and idiomatic expressions, and on acquisition of new vocabulary.
courses.prerequisites: SPAN 2160 or equivalent. Honors Eligibility required

courses.course_description: Course emphasizes writing at an advanced level, with a certain degree of sophistication about varied subjects and using different techniques of composition.  Classwork consists mainly of the discussion of both the ideas and techniques used in different textual forms.
Study Abroad Conversational Spanish course for students who have already completed SPAN 3150, but want more practice.  Does not count for majors/minors.  Graded on A-F basis only.
Business terminology and forms. Translate and compose business letters and documents for advertising and promotion, trade and commerce, imports and exports, money and banking.

Study of Mexican culture and civilization through field trips, excursions and selected readings in Mexican history and literature. No knowledge of Spanish required. Open only to participants in UMC's study programs in Mexico.
Selected prose fiction and nonfiction prose of Spain and Spanish America.

courses.course_name: Introduction to Hispanic Literature I - Writing Intensive
courses.course_description: Selected prose fiction and nonfiction prose of Spain and Spanish America.
Selected plays and poetry of Spain and Spanish America.

courses.course_name: Introduction to Hispanic Literature II - Honors
courses.course_description: Selected plays and poetry of Spain and Spanish America.
courses.prerequisites: SPAN 3160 or equivalent.  Honors eligibility required

courses.course_name: Introduction to Hispanic Literature II - Writing Intensive
courses.course_description: Selected plays and poetry of Spain and Spanish America.

courses.course_name: Survey of Minority and Creole Languages of the U.S. and the Caribbean
courses.course_description: (same as FRENCH 3710 and LINGST 3710). Analysis of the state of the minority languages of the U.S. and the Creole languages of the Caribbean with particular attention to the social status of these languages and speakers' attitudes toward them in the context of ethnic, culture and national identity (taught in Eng.).

(same as LINGST 3721). Introductory course to the study of Spanish phonological, phonetic and spelling systems, practice of pronunciation, phonetic transcriptions, and introduction to the variation of Spanish pronunciation in the Hispanic world.  The course is conducted in Spanish.

(same as FILM_S 3885, PORT 3885). Broad overview of the major national cinemas of the 21st century in South America. Approximately 14 feature films screened from Argentina, Brazil, Chile and other nations of the region. Instructor provides a thematic framework for films within the context of film theory, Latin American cinematic history and cultural studies. Course taught in English. Graded on A-F basis only.
Designed for rapid acquisition of a reading knowledge of Spanish. Cannot be taken to fulfill undergraduate language requirement.

(same as FRENCH 4120). Theory and techniques of current foreign language methodology and their application in the classroom. Presentation of instructional projects, classroom observations, and strategies for classroom management. May not be used towards Arts and Science major.

Advanced composition class.  Discussion of complex grammatical structures necessary for formal writing.  Examination of stylistic devices and structures beyond sentence level, in order to learn to organize discourse level production.

Advanced composition class.  Discussion of complex grammatical structures necessary for formal writing.  Examination of stylistic devices and structures beyond sentence level, in order to learn to organize discourse level production.

The principal periods, schools, and genres of Spanish medieval literature are surveyed through representative masterworks. Lectures and periodic student reports help relate works read to the rest of contemporary Spanish and European literature.

Poetry of the principal Spanish poets of the 16th and 17th centuries and of literary criticism devoted to it.  Special emphasis is placed on the works of Garcilaso de la Vega, Fray Luis de Leon, among others.  Short papers and explications are generally required.

Representative prose works from various genres are read as well as literary criticism devoted to them.  Among the authors studied are Fernando de Rojas, Jorje Montemayor, Miguel de Cervantes, Francisco de Quevedo, and Maria de Zayas.

courses.course_name: Spanish Theatre in the Golden Age
courses.course_description: Dramatists to be studied include Lope de Vega, Calderon, Ruiz de Alarcon, Tirso de Molina, Guillen de Castro, Velez de Guevara, and some of Cervantes' theatre.

In this course students read the two parts of Don Quijote in the original Spanish.  Analysis and class discussion highlight elements of literary interest.  Neo-positivist methodology, factual background, formalist considerations and psychoanalytic approaches are used in this course.

(cross-leveled with SPAN 7441). Reading and critical analysis of representative novels written in Spain from early century to the post-Franco period.  The objectives of the course are to develop critical skills in dealing with these fictional works and to understand the major trends of the contemporary Spanish novel.
(cross-leveled with SPAN 7442). Study of Spanish culture and civilization through field trips, excursions, and selected readings in history, literature, and contemporary print media.
courses.prerequisites: SPAN 3150, SPAN 3160, SPAN 3721 or equivalent. Open only to participants in the UMC's summer study in Spain

courses.course_description: A study of the literature of commitment in the Hispanic world: literature in its historical and political contexts that makes a conscious effort to change social conditions.

courses.course_name: Advanced Contemporary Culture of Spanish America
courses.course_description: (cross-leveled with SPAN 7460). A study of Spanish-American culture and civilization through selected readings in history and literature, and the use of visual media. Graded on A-F basis only.

(cross-leveled with SPAN 7461). A survey of Spanish culture and Spanish history from the Middle Ages to the present with special emphasis on contemporary culture. Students will be provided with knowledge of chronology, geography and contemporary issues from readings of journals, novels and Internet news.

courses.course_name: Survey of Spanish American Literature I
courses.course_description: This is an introductory course in Spanish American literature. The reading material in prose and verse is studied in chronological order from the early 16th to the early 20th century.  Readings include selections from 22 major Spanish American authors.

courses.course_name: Survey of Spanish American Literature II
courses.course_description: Survey of contemporary Latin American literature from approximately 1910 to the present.  Close analysis and reading of representative major texts of Latin American literature.  Students read complete selections and short excerpts from a standard anthology, and three complete novels.

Analysis of selected poetry, prose, and drama of contemporary Mexico.  Course examines the writings of major and minor figures from several critical perspectives.  Works by Agustin, Aviles, Fabila, Carballido, Castellanos, Fuentes, Paz, and others are read.
This course proposes to examine the Hispanic Oral Tradition through a study of romances and related genres, the corrido, decima and folktale.

Careful study and analysis of selected poems by major figures in Hispanic poetry.  The period covered includes the modernist movement to the present.  Particular attention is given to the following figures: Ruben Dario, Octavio Paz, Pablo Neruda, and Nicolas Guillen.

Intended as an overview of a vital genre in contemporary Spanish American studies, this survey introduces dramatists whose works are the focus of increasing attention from international specialists.  The works of Emilio Carballido, Egon Wolff, Griselda Gambaro and Osvald Dragun, among others are discussed.
A study of prose, poetry, and drama, in Spanish, written by authors of African descent in the Americas.

courses.course_name: Nobel Laureates in Spanish American Literature
courses.course_description: Analyzes the creative expression of five Nobel laureates from Spanish America. Selected works of Gabriela Mistral, Pablo Neruda, Miguel Angel Asturias, Octavio Paz and Gabriel Garcia Marquez are read in relation to contemporary theory.
(same as LINGST 4711). Diachronic analysis of phonological, morphological, and syntactical systems of Spanish, from Vulgar Latin to contemporary dialects.
courses.prerequisites: Completion with a passing grade of any Linguistics course at the 3000 level or above or instructor's consent

courses.course_description: (same as LINGST 4721). Synchronic analysis of phonology, morphology and syntax of spoken Spanish dialects.

(same as LINGST 4722).  This course focuses on the effects of migratory movements on language change, considering the Spanish spoken in Latin America, Puerto Rico, Spain and the USA.  The class sharpens awareness and recognition of the linguistic diversity of the Spanish-speaking regions of the world.  Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.course_name: Spanish Across the Continents - Writing Intensive
courses.course_description: (same as LINGST 4722).  This course focuses on the effects of migratory movements on language change, considering the Spanish spoken in Latin America, Puerto Rico, Spain and the USA.  The class sharpens awareness and recognition of the linguistic diversity of the Spanish-speaking regions of the world.  Graded on A-F basis only.

(same as LINGST 4723). This class surveys linguistic and social issues pertaining to Spanish in the U.S. (past, present and future).  Topics include bilingualism, code switching (a.k.a. Spanglish), first language attrition, linguistic identity, and the role of Spanish in education, services and media.  Graded on A-F basis only.

(same as RM_LAN 4940). Course offers our majors and advanced minors the opportunity to use their language skills in real-life community settings. Does not meet Art  and Science general education requirements. May be repeated once for credit. Graded on S/U basis only.
courses.prerequisites: junior or senior standing and departmental consent

courses.course_description: Independent study through readings, conferences, reports.
courses.prerequisites: SPAN 3420 and SPAN 3430 and departmental consent

courses.course_description: Subject varies according to instructor.  May be repeated for credit.

This course is required of all majors.  Topics vary but all courses synthesize and review essential components of the major: speaking, writing, reading in Spanish, and the ability to think critically and analytically.
Organized study of selected topics. Subjects and earnable credit may vary from semester to semester. May be repeated for credit with departmental consent.

(same as FRENCH 7120). Theory and techniques of current foreign language methodology and their application in the classroom. Presentation of instructional projects, classroom observations, and strategies for classroom management. May not be used towards Arts and Science major.

Advanced composition class.  Discussion of complex grammatical structures necessary for formal writing.  Examination of stylistic devices and structures beyond sentence level, in order to learn to organize discourse level production.

courses.course_description: Analyzes the creative expression of five Nobel laureates from Spanish America. Selected works of Gabriela Mistral, Pablo Neruda, Miguel Angel Asturias, Octavio Paz and Gabriel Garcia Marquez are read in relation to contemporary theory.
(same as LINGST 7711). Diachronic analysis of phonology, morphology, and syntax from Vulgar Latin to modern period.
courses.prerequisites: Completion with a passing grade of any Linguistics course at the 3000 level or above or instructor's consent

courses.course_description: (same as LINGST 7721). Synchronic analysis of phonology, morphology and syntax of spoken Spanish dialects.

The class sharpens awareness and recognition of the linguistic diversity of the Spanish-speaking regions of the world.   Graded on A-F basis only.

Spanglish), first language attrition, linguistic identity, and the role of Spanish in education, services and media.  Graded on A-F basis only.
Independent study through readings, conferences, reports.
Subject varies according to instructor.
Topics vary but all courses synthesize and review essential components of the major: speaking, writing, reading in Spanish, and the ability to think critically and analytically.
Independent readings in preparation for MA or MALT comprehensive examination in Spanish.  Graded on A-F basis only.
Problems in Spanish.
Subject varies according to instructor.
Leads to preparation of MA or MALT thesis.  Graded on S/U basis only.

(same as FRENCH 8120 and LINGST 8120). Global analysis of the study of Bilingualism from a combined sociocultural, sociolinguistic and psycholinguistic perspective based on current research and examination of various phenomena of language contact (taught in English).

courses.course_name: Studies in Spanish Literature of the Medieval Period
courses.course_description: Studies in Spanish Literature of the Medieval Period.

courses.course_name: Studies in Spanish Literature of the Renaissance
courses.course_description: Studies in Spanish Literature of the Renaissance

courses.course_name: Studies in Spanish Literature in the Golden Age
courses.course_description: Studies in Spanish Literature in the Golden Age
Studies in Nineteenth-Century Spanish Literature
Studies in Twentieth-Century Spanish Literature

courses.course_name: Studies in Colonial Spanish American Literature
courses.course_description: Analysis of seminal literary and ""Historical"" texts interpreting the Encounter, Conquest and Colonization of Spanish America.
Studies in Spanish-American Fiction
Studies in Latin American Literature

courses.prerequisites: knowledge of Latin, to be demonstrated by passing departmental written examination or by completing LATIN 7110 with grade of B or better

courses.course_description: Independent readings in preparation for Ph.D. comprehensive examination in Spanish.
Leads to preparation of PhD dissertation in Spanish. Graded on S/U basis only.
